title: Second Kumaraswamy ministry
text:
H. D. Kumaraswamy was the Council of Ministers in Karnataka, a state in <a href="South%20India">South India</a> headed by <a href="H.%20D.%20Kumaraswamy">H. D. Kumaraswamy</a> that was formed after the <a href="2018%20Karnataka%20Legislative%20Assembly%20election">2018 Karnataka Legislative Assembly election</a>s.
In the <a href="Government%20of%20Karnataka">government</a> headed by <a href="H.%20D.%20Kumaraswamy">H. D. Kumaraswamy</a>, the <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Chief Minister</a> was from <a href="Janata%20Dal%20%28Secular%29">JD(S)</a> while <a href="Deputy%20Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Deputy Chief Minister</a> was from <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">INC</a>. Apart from the <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">CM</a> & <a href="Deputy%20Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Deputy CM</a>, there were 32 ministers in the government, but all the 32 ministers resigned from their posts in July 2019 due to political turmoil in Karnataka.
Tenure of the Government.
After the <a href="2018%20Karnataka%20Legislative%20Assembly%20election">2018 assembly elections</a>, <a href="Bharatiya%20Janata%20Party">BJP</a> emerged as the single largest party with 104 seats, followed by the <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">INC</a> with 78 seats and <a href="Janata%20Dal%20%28Secular%29">JD(S)</a> with 37 seats. <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">INC</a> extended the support to <a href="Janata%20Dal%20%28Secular%29">JD(S)</a> to form the <a href="Government%20of%20Karnataka">government</a>. Governor <a href="Vajubhai%20Vala">Vajubhai Vala</a> invited <a href="Bharatiya%20Janata%20Party">BJP</a> to form the government and <a href="B.%20S.%20Yeddyurappa">B. S. Yeddyurappa</a> was sworn in as the <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Chief Minister</a>. But <a href="B.%20S.%20Yeddyurappa">B. S. Yeddyurappa</a> could not prove the majority of his government and resigned after 2 days of being sworn in. After that, <a href="H.%20D.%20Kumaraswamy">H. D. Kumaraswamy</a> of the <a href="Janata%20Dal%20%28Secular%29">JD(S)</a> was sworn in as the <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Chief Minister</a>, with the support of <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">INC</a>, <a href="Bahujan%20Samaj%20Party">BSP</a>, <a href="Karnataka%20Pragnyavantha%20Janatha%20Party">KPJP</a> and <a href="Independent%20politician">IND</a> MLA. <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">INC</a> MLA <a href="G%20Parameshwara">Dr. G. Parameshwara</a> was sworn in as the <a href="Deputy%20Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Deputy Chief Minister</a>, along with <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Chief Minister</a> <a href="H.%20D.%20Kumaraswamy">H. D. Kumaraswamy</a>. On 6 June 2018, 25 ministers were inducted in the cabinet.
In <a href="2019%20Karnataka%20resignation%20crisis">July 2019</a>, 13 MLAs from the <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">INC</a> and 3 MLAs from the <a href="Janata%20Dal%20%28Secular%29">JD(S)</a> resigned from the <a href="Karnataka%20Legislative%20Assembly">assembly</a>, thus pushing the government to a minority. 1 <a href="Karnataka%20Pragnyavantha%20Janatha%20Party">KPJP</a> and 1 <a href="Independent%20politician">IND</a> MLA also withdrew their support from the <a href="Government%20of%20Karnataka">government</a> and extended their support to <a href="Bharatiya%20Janata%20Party">BJP</a>. The rebel MLAs left <a href="Bangalore">Bangalore</a> and camped in a resort in <a href="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>. To pacify the disgruntled MLAs, 32 ministers, excluding the <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Chief Minister</a> and <a href="List%20of%20Deputy%20Chief%20Ministers%20of%20Karnataka">Deputy Chief Minister</a>, resigned from the ministerial posts. On 18 July, Chief Minister <a href="H.%20D.%20Kumaraswamy">H. D. Kumaraswamy</a> moved the <a href="trust%20vote">trust vote</a> in the house. Finally on 23 July, after 3 days long debate, the trust vote was put for voting, in which 204 members participated in the voting process. The government lost the majority by getting 99 votes, compared to the 105 votes of the <a href="Bharatiya%20Janata%20Party">BJP</a>, after which <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Karnataka">Chief Minister</a> <a href="H.%20D.%20Kumaraswamy">H. D. Kumaraswamy</a> resigned from the post.
Council of Ministers.
Former Members.
On 8 July 2019, 32 ministers resigned from their posts after the political turmoil in state. But their resignation was not accepted, although the chief minister's office announced that the ministers have resigned.
